instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.CPU_VR_EN: What is CPU_VR_EN? CPU_VR_EN is an enable signal for CPU VCORE that is present when it is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. ALL_SYS_PWRGD, PM_RSMRST_L, PM_SLP_SUS_L, and PM_SLP_S3_L are necessary prerequisites for CPU_VR_EN to be present. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> Pulsing
threads.message:
Clean board, old but clean

PPBUS: 8.58V
3V42: 3.4V
<SIGNAL>VRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.3V
<SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>: 5V
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 3.3V
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 3.3V

Checked all coils for shorts and nothing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> Pulsing
threads.message:
Check for pulse on all coils.
Also check <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pins 7 & 3.

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulsing too?
Just in case, test SMC bypass...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> Pulsing
threads.message:
Missing L3095,
Pulsing L7520, L7130, L7630, L7430
Steady L7560

<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> Pins 7 & 3 pulsing.
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
SMC bypass same thing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> Pulsing
threads.message:
So no pulse at CPU core coils for sure?
What is diode mode reading there?
Compare with good board.

<SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN</SIGNAL> pulsing?
Also check <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_READY</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> Pulsing
threads.message:
Sorry about that L7630, L7430, L7310 and L7320 are also pulsing, I don't know why I did not see that in the first place.

<SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_READY</SIGNAL> also pulses about every 4 seconds.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> Pulsing
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulsing too?
If yes, check for pulse all PCH's rails from page 11.
May have a broken coil, or resistor.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> Pulsing
threads.message:
Checked the resistors on page 11 as well as coils and caps, all are fine.

Put board on oven for 15 minutes and now it is working, maybe PCH is dying, lets see.

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> Pulsing
threads.message:
Very likely accumulated crap underneath PCH.
heating with quality flux, was the next step in the process.
